rule.description: Office 365: SharePoint list content type events.
Office 365: A permission level was added to a site collection.
Office 365: Data loss protection (DLP) events in SharePoint and OneDrive for Business.
Office 365: Events from the Exchange admin audit log.
Office 365: Events from an Exchange mailbox audit log for actions that are performed on a single item, such as creating or receiving an email message.
Office 365: Events from an Exchange mailbox audit log for actions that can be performed on multiple items, such as moving or deleted one or more email messages.
Office 365: Azure Active Directory OrgId logon events (deprecated).
Office 365: Data Center security cmdlet events.
Office 365: Data loss protection (DLP) events in Exchange, when configured via Unified DLP Policy. DLP events based on Exchange Transport Rules are not supported.
Office 365: Secure Token Service (STS) logon events in Azure Active Directory.
Office 365: Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN) events from Skype for Business.
Office 365: Blocked user events from Skype for Business.
Office 365: Admin actions from the Security and Compliance Center.
Office 365: Aggregated Exchange mailbox auditing events.
Office 365: Events for eDiscovery activities performed by running content searches and managing eDiscovery cases in the Security and Compliance Center.
Office 365: Phishing and malware events from Exchange Online Protection and Microsoft Defender for Office 365.
Office 365: Submission events from Exchange Online Protection and Microsoft Defender for Office 365.
Office 365: Microsoft Power Automate (formerly called Microsoft Flow) events.
Office 365: Events related to DLP classification in SharePoint.
Office 365: Campaign-related events from Microsoft Defender for Office 365.
Office 365: Events related to retention policies and retention labels in the Security and Compliance Center.
Office 365: Security and compliance alert signals.
Office 365: Safe links time-of-block and block override events from Microsoft Defender for Office 365.
Office 365: Events related to insights and reports in the Office 365 security and compliance center.
Office 365: Events related to the detection in the Transport pipeline of email messages that have been tagged (manually or automatically) with sensitivity labels.
Office 365: Subscription plan events for Power Apps.
Office 365: Phishing and malware events for files in SharePoint, OneDrive for Business, and Microsoft Teams from Microsoft Defender for Office 365.
Office 365: Events related to data classification content explorer.
Office 365: Events related to the Patients application in Microsoft Teams for Healthcare.
Office 365: Events related to the MailItemsAccessed mailbox auditing action.
Office 365: Events related to outbound spam protection.
Office 365: Data Insights REST API events.
Office 365: Events related to the application of information barrier policies.
Office 365: Events related to HR data signals that support the Insider risk management solution.
Office 365: Events related to compromised user alerts.
Office 365: Email campaign events from Microsoft Defender for Office 365.
Office 365: Events tracked by the Communication compliance offensive language model.
Office 365: Events related to the customer key encryption service.
Office 365: Events related to sensitivity labels applied to Office documents.
Office 365: Auto-labeling policy events in SharePoint.
Office 365: Events related to performing search queries in SharePoint and Exchange.
Office 365: Events related to alerts generated by Windows Defender for Endpoint.
Office 365: Microsoft Defender for Endpoint events.
Office 365: Events generated when the file labeled with a sensitivity label is opened or renamed.
Office 365: Event generated when sensitivity labels are applied, updated, or removed from a file.
Office 365: Events generated when a file labeled with a sensitivity label is opened or renamed.
Office 365: Events related to manual investigations in Automated investigation and response (AIR).
Office 365: Security and compliance RBAC events.
Office 365: Attack simulator training events in Microsoft Defender for Office 365.
Office 365: Events related to admin actions in Automated investigation and response (AIR).
Office 365: Threat intelligence events in Microsoft Defender for Office 365.
Office 365: Events related to physical badging signals that support the Insider risk management solution.
Office 365: Azure Information Protection (AIP) scanner events.
Office 365: Events corresponding to alerts triggered by Microsoft Cloud App Security.
Office 365: Events related to scanning for sensitive data on file shares.
Office 365: Events related to scanning for sensitive data in SharePoint.
Office 365: Events related to using Outlook on the web (OWA) to search for mailbox items.
Office 365: Events related to searching an organization's SharePoint home site.
Office 365: Events related to modifying or deleting a user.
Office 365: Exact Data Match (EDM) classification events.
Office 365: Sent message using different permissions
Office 365: Added credentials to a service principal
Office 365: User $(UserId) got FullAccess permissions in Exchange
Failed login attempt in Azure AD due to account lockout.
User login failed Azure AD MFA interrupted due to incomplete authentication.
User login failed in Azure Active Directory due to device authentication issues.
Office 365: Phishing detections led to emails being delivered to the inbox.
MSO365: Phishing email is delivered without any action taken
MSO365: Detects activity from a location not recently or ever visited by any user within the organization
rule.info: Description: This detection identifies instances where Microsoft Cloud App Security reports activity originating from a location that has not been recently or has never been visited by any user within the organization. Such activity might indicate unauthorized access or potential compromise, as attackers often leverage unfamiliar or uncommon locations to avoid detection. Monitoring and analyzing this event can help in promptly identifying suspicious behavior and mitigating potential security threats.

rule.description: MSO365: Detects IP addresses are linked to malicious activities like Botnet CnC, signaling potential threats.
rule.info: Description: This detection identifies activity originating from IP addresses known to be associated with malicious activities, including Botnet Command and Control (CnC) operations. Such behavior is indicative of a potential threat, suggesting that these IPs may be part of a larger malicious infrastructure targeting your environment.

rule.description: MSO365: Detects when Microsoft Cloud App Security flags a risky sign-in attempt involving impossible travel for login.
rule.info: Description: Detection identifies when Microsoft Cloud App Security flags a sign-in attempt involving "impossible travel"—where a user logs in from two geographically distant locations within a time frame that would make physical travel impossible. This is often a strong indicator of account compromise or unauthorized access, as legitimate users are unlikely to generate such events.

rule.description: MSO365:Detects user signs into Microsoft Cloud App Security sanctioned apps from a flagged risky IP address.
rule.info: Description: Detection identifies when Microsoft Cloud App Security reports a user signing into sanctioned applications from a risky or anonymous IP address. Such IP addresses are often associated with proxy services, VPNs, or Tor networks used to hide the true origin of the connection, potentially indicating suspicious or unauthorized access attempts.

rule.description: MSO365: Detects when Microsoft Cloud App Security flags potential ransomware-infected cloud uploads.
rule.info: Description: This detection identifies instances where Microsoft Cloud App Security flags suspicious cloud uploads that could be indicative of ransomware infection. This activity could involve encrypting files and uploading them to cloud storage, which is a common tactic used by ransomware operators to extort organizations by threatening data loss or exposure.

rule.description: MSO365: Detects suspicious email forwarding rules to external addresses in Microsoft Cloud App Security.
rule.info: Description: This detection identifies suspicious email forwarding rules being configured to send messages to external addresses, as reported by Microsoft Cloud App Security. Such rules could indicate an attempt by attackers to exfiltrate sensitive data by forwarding incoming emails to unauthorized recipients without the user’s knowledge.

rule.description: MSO365: Detects unusual multiple file downloads from SharePoint or OneDrive by a user.
rule.info: Description: This detection identifies unusual or suspicious multiple file downloads from SharePoint or OneDrive by a user via an OAuth application. Excessive file downloads in a short period may indicate potential misuse of OAuth app permissions or a compromised account, often linked to credential theft or data exfiltration attempts.

rule.description: MSO365: Detects when Microsoft Cloud App Security reports unusual large file deletions by user.
rule.info: Description: This detection identifies instances where Microsoft Cloud App Security reports an unusually large number of file deletions by a user. Such activity may indicate malicious intent, such as attempts to cover up traces of unauthorized access or data exfiltration. High-volume deletions can be a red flag for defensive evasion tactics or an indicator of a compromised account.

rule.description: MSO365: Detects when a Security Compliance Center reports a user restricted from sending emails due to exceeding service policy limits.
rule.info: Description: This detection identifies cases where the Security Compliance Center reports a user being restricted from sending emails due to exceeding service policy limits. This restriction could be triggered by various policy thresholds, such as limits on the number of emails sent within a specific time frame or compliance-related restrictions.

rule.description: MSO365: Detects when Microsoft Cloud App Security reports unsanctioned app usage resembling data exfiltration attempts.
rule.info: Description: This detection identifies when Microsoft Cloud App Security reports activity involving data transfer to applications that are not sanctioned by the organization. Such behavior may indicate attempts to exfiltrate sensitive information to unauthorized or unapproved applications, which could be a sign of malicious data theft or insider threats.

Description: This detection identifies successful login attempts to non-primary mailboxes (i.e., mailboxes other than the user’s default or primary mailbox). The rule triggers when a login operation is performed and the logon type is not standard (indicated by a logon type of 0, which is generally not used for regular logins). This could indicate unusual or unauthorized access to secondary or shared mailboxes.

rule.description: MSO365: Data loss prevention logging detected.
rule.info: Description: This detection identifies when data loss prevention (DLP) logging activities are triggered in Office 365 for a specific tenant. DLP rules are used to protect sensitive information from being accidentally or maliciously shared, and logging these events is crucial for identifying potential data exfiltration attempts.

Description: This detection identifies when MailFlow logging activities are triggered within Office 365 for a specific tenant. MailFlow logs track the movement and delivery of email messages, which can provide insights into email communication patterns, potential data collection, or mail routing issues.

Description: This detection identifies when Threat Management logging activities are triggered within Office 365 for a specific tenant. Threat Management logs capture security events related to threat detection, incident response, and investigation, providing insights into potential malicious activity or threat discovery attempts.

rule.field: (?i)sidbi dlp policy - exchange online - external domain exclude
rule.info: Description: This detection identifies when a Data Loss Prevention (DLP) policy violation occurs within Office 365 for a specific tenant. It monitors the tenant for any actions that contravene DLP policies, except for those specified by the sidbi dlp policy - exchange online - external domain exclude. DLP policies help prevent sensitive data from being shared or transferred outside the organization.

rule.match: (?i).*(This alert is triggered when any email message is reported as not junk by users -V1.0.0.0).*
rule.description: MSO365: User Reported 'Not Junk' Email Alert
rule.info: Description: This detection identifies when a user reports an email message as "Not Junk" within Office 365 for the specified tenant. The rule is triggered when the operation matches the alert pattern where users indicate that an email flagged as junk is not malicious. This may indicate users unknowingly interacting with potentially harmful emails, possibly resulting in policy violations.

rule.description: MSO365: Phishing or malware emails were delivered and have been either rejected,quarantined or sent to the Junk folder
rule.info: Description: This rule identifies instances where phishing or malware-laden emails have been delivered to recipients and subsequently quarantined, rejected, or moved to the Junk folder by email protection policies. This activity signifies that malicious content managed to bypass initial email defenses, reaching the recipient's inbox, and was later caught by more stringent security filter.

rule.description: MSO365 : Authentication failure detected for IFFCOADMIN.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects failed authentication attempts associated with the IFFCOADMIN user account in the IFFCO tenant. Repeated login failures on such a privileged account could indicate a brute-force attack or unauthorized access attempt. Immediate action should be taken to investigate the cause of the failed attempts and determine whether there is a potential compromise of admin credentials.

Description: This rule identifies successful authentication attempts for the IFFCOADMIN user account in the IFFCO tenant. As this account holds high-level administrative privileges, any successful login should be carefully monitored to ensure it is legitimate. Unauthorized access to this account could lead to severe security risks, including administrative control over critical systems and data.

rule.description: MSO365: External user added in Microsoft Teams
rule.info: Description: This rule detects when an external user (identified by #EXT# in the UPN) is added to a Microsoft Teams channel within the IFFCO tenant. External users may represent a security risk if not properly vetted, as they could gain access to sensitive information and resources within the Teams environment. Monitoring such events helps ensure that external collaborations are authorized and do not expose the organization to potential data leaks or unauthorized access.

rule.description: MSO365: External user removed from Microsoft Teams
rule.info: Description: This rule detects when an external user (identified by #EXT# in the UPN) is removed from a Microsoft Teams channel within the IFFCO tenant. While the removal of external users may indicate a legitimate termination of collaboration, it is important to verify such actions to ensure no unauthorized users were added or retained in the system without proper removal procedures. Monitoring external user removals helps ensure that organizational data remains protected even after external collaborations end.

rule.description: MSO365: File Uploaded Operation in Microsoft Teams.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects when a file is uploaded to the Microsoft Teams Chat Files section in the IFFCO tenant. Monitoring file uploads within Teams is crucial to ensure that potentially malicious files are not shared within the organization. This detection highlights potential suspicious activity, especially if external actors or unauthorized users are involved in file sharing, which could lead to the execution of malicious payloads or unauthorized data access.

rule.description: MSO365: File accessed Operation in Microsoft Teams.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects when a file is accessed in the Microsoft Teams Chat Files section within the IFFCO tenant. File access tracking within Microsoft Teams helps ensure that sensitive data is not being improperly viewed, especially by unauthorized users or external parties. Accessing files in Teams can be a normal activity, but monitoring these events allows for detection of any suspicious behavior, particularly if linked to prior uploads of potentially malicious files.

rule.description: MSO365: Suspicious Exchange Inbox Rules Detected in Email Content.
rule.info: Description: This rule identifies suspicious inbox rules created in Exchange, where messages containing specific keywords like "helpdesk," "alert," "suspicious," or phishing-related terms are being redirected, deleted, or moved to folders like "Deleted Items" or "Junk Email." This can indicate an adversary's attempt to hide phishing emails or mask their tracks by creating rules that automatically handle suspicious content.

rule.description: MSO365: Microsoft Teams deleted by a single user
rule.info: Description: This rule triggers when a Microsoft Teams instance is deleted by a single user in an IFFCO tenant. Deleting a team can result in the removal of essential data, collaboration channels, and communication history, which can lead to data loss or disruption.

rule.description: MSO365: IFFCOADMIN user account creation detected
rule.info: Description: The detection rule triggers an alert when a user account named IFFCOADMIN is created within the IFFCO tenant in Microsoft Office 365. This specific user account may be intended for administrative purposes and could potentially have elevated privileges. Monitoring the creation of such accounts is critical, as it may indicate unauthorized or suspicious activity.

rule.description: MSO365: User Account was deleted by the IFFCOADMIN
rule.info: Description: This detection rule triggers when a user account is deleted by the IFFCOADMIN. It ensures that any deletion activity carried out by this specific user is monitored for potential unauthorized or suspicious actions.

Description: This rule monitors the creation of new users in the Office 365 environment by the IFFCOADMIN account. It is designed to detect potential unauthorized user account creations or administrative activities that could signal a compromise or misuse of the IFFCOADMIN account.

Description: This rule triggers when privileges are changed by a user with the identifier IFFCOADMIN. This detection is essential for monitoring potential unauthorized privilege escalations,particularly by IFFCOADMIN, which could indicate a compromise or misuse of elevated privileges within the organization.

rule.description: MSO365: IFFCOADMIN User account deletion detected.
rule.info: Description: The detection rule monitors the deletion of the user account "IFFCOADMIN". The user "IFFCOADMIN" is critical, and its deletion could indicate an unauthorized or unexpected action within the organization.

Description: This rule detects when email forwarding is configured in Microsoft 365, potentially indicating unauthorized redirection of emails to external addresses. It helps identify possible data exfiltration or malicious activity by monitoring changes to email forwarding settings.

rule.description: MSO365: Exchange transport rule email forwarding detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule identifies when an Exchange transport rule is configured in Microsoft 365 to forward emails, which may indicate unauthorized redirection or potential data leakage. It helps monitor and prevent misuse of email forwarding rules within the organization.

rule.description: MSO365: File Download or upload Event Detected in SharePoint.
rule.info: Description: The rule detects file download events in SharePoint within Microsoft 365, helping to monitor and track file access. It assists in identifying potential data exfiltration or unauthorized access to sensitive documents.

rule.description: MSO365: Rare and potentially high-risk Office operations
rule.info: Description: The rule identifies rare or unusual Office operations in Microsoft 365 that could pose a high risk, such as uncommon file accesses or changes. It helps in detecting potentially suspicious or malicious activities within the Office environment.

rule.description: MSO365: Exchange audit log disabled by admin.
rule.info: Description: The rule detects when an administrator disables the Exchange audit log in Microsoft 365, which could indicate an attempt to conceal unauthorized activities. Monitoring this action is crucial for maintaining audit integrity and security visibility.

Description: The rule detects when a policy within Microsoft 365 is altered or tampered with, which may indicate an attempt to weaken security controls. Monitoring these events helps ensure that critical policies remain intact and unmodified by unauthorized users.

rule.description: MSO365: Executable Upload event detected in Office 365.
rule.info: Description: The rule indicates that a new file has been successfully uploaded to a SharePoint site within the Office 365 environment. It serves as a trigger for actions or alerts related to the file's upload.

rule.description: MSO365: Executable Upload event detected in Office 365.
rule.info: Description: The rule indicates that a new file has been successfully uploaded to a SharePoint site within the Office 365 environment. It serves as a trigger for actions or alerts related to the file's upload.

Description: The rule indicates that an email within the Office 365 environment has been accessed by a user, admin, or automated system. This event helps track email access activity for security and compliance purposes.

rule.description: MSO365: Multiple time Authentication failed from same user
rule.info: Description: This detection identifies multiple authentication failures from the same user within a specific tenant in Office 365. The rule is triggered when 5 failed login attempts from the same user and IP address occur within an hour. This could indicate a brute-force attack or credential-stuffing attempt, where an attacker tries to gain unauthorized access to the user's account.

rule.description: MSO365: File Accessed in Microsoft Teams by More Than 10 Users Within 1 Hour
rule.info: Description: This rule triggers when the same file within Microsoft Teams Chat Files is accessed by more than 10 distinct users within 1 hour for the IFFCO tenant. Such activity may indicate potential information dissemination or abnormal collaboration behavior.

rule.description: MSO365: Microsoft Teams Deleted by 3 Users Within One Hour.
rule.info: Description: This rule triggers when Microsoft Teams is deleted by three different users within one hour in an IFFCO tenant. This could indicate coordinated malicious activity or a significant issue with user accounts.

rule.description: MSO365: Multiple mailboxes forwarding same destination.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects when multiple mailboxes in Microsoft 365 are configured to forward emails to the same destination, which could indicate coordinated data exfiltration or unauthorized email collection by an attacker.

rule.description: MSO365: File Upload or download operation with different user-agent detected.
rule.info: Description: The rule detects when a file is downloaded from Microsoft 365 with a User-Agent that differs from the expected or usual User-Agent patterns. Unusual User-Agents could indicate potentially unauthorized access or suspicious activity.

rule.description: MSO365: File Upload or download operation from different ClientIP detected.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects when a file is uploaded or downloaded in Microsoft 365 from an unusual or different IP address, indicating potential unauthorized access. It helps in identifying suspicious activity and possible security breaches.

rule.description: MSO365: Suspicious Executable Upload detected in Office 365.
rule.info: Description: The rule detects when executable files, such as .exe, .cmd, and .bat, are uploaded to Office services like SharePoint or OneDrive. It also tracks if a user uploads these files to another user's workspace.

rule.description: MSO365: Multiple DeleteDataset operations detected in a short period from the same source.
rule.info: Description: This rule triggers when five or more DeleteDataset operations are detected within a 10-minute timeframe from the same source IP, tenant, and user ID. The activity may indicate a potential data destruction attempt.

rule.description: MSO365: Multiple GenerateScreenshot operations detected in a short period from the same source.
rule.info: Description: This rule triggers when five or more GenerateScreenshot operations are detected within a 10-minute timeframe from the same tenant and user ID. This could indicate potential unauthorized screen capture activity.

rule.description: MSO365: Multiple GetSnapshots operations detected in a short period from the same source.
rule.info: Description: This rule triggers when five or more GetSnapshots operations are detected within a 10-minute timeframe from the same tenant and user ID. This can indicate potential unauthorized screen capture or snapshot activity, which may signal malicious intent.

rule.description: MSO365: Multiple Delete user operations detected in a short period from the same source.
rule.info: Description: This rule is triggered when multiple Delete User operations are executed from the same source (tenant and user) within a 10-minute timeframe. It monitors for a surge in user deletion activities that may signal unauthorized account access removal or large-scale user deletion.

rule.description: MSO365: Phishing and malware events from Exchange Online Protection and Microsoft Defender for Office 365
rule.info: Description: This rule is triggered when phishing or malware events are detected from Exchange Online Protection and Microsoft Defender for Office 365. The detection involves cases where no action is taken against a threat (such as malware or phishing), but the email is still delivered or delivered as spam.

rule.description: MSO365: External User Added and Removed from Microsoft Teams Within 1 Hour.
rule.info: Description: This rule detects scenarios where an external user is first added to a Microsoft Teams group and then quickly removed. This sequence of actions might indicate an attempt to manipulate account settings or hide unauthorized access to sensitive information.

rule.description: MSO365: O365: Multiple GenerateScreenshot and GetSnapshots operations detected in a short period from the same source.
rule.info: Description: This rule is triggered when multiple GenerateScreenshot and GetSnapshots operations are detected from the same source (tenant and user) within a 10-minute timeframe. It correlates both operations, potentially indicating malicious activity aimed at screen capture or unauthorized collection of sensitive visual data.

rule.description: MSO365: Multiple Failed Login Followed by Successful Login.
rule.info: Description: This detection identifies multiple failed login attempts from a user, followed by a successful login within the same timeframe. The rule is triggered if 5 failed attempts occur within an hour, followed by a successful login from the same user and IP address. This sequence might indicate that an attacker successfully guessed or used compromised credentials after several attempts, potentially pointing to a brute-force attack or credential-stuffing success.

rule.description: MSO365: File Uploaded and Accessed by More Than 10 user via Microsoft Teams Chat Files.
rule.info: Description: This correlation rule detects when a file is both uploaded and accessed by more than 10 distinct users within 1 hour in Microsoft Teams Chat Files for the IFFCO tenant. This combined behavior suggests potential data exfiltration or misuse, especially when the same file is rapidly distributed and accessed across multiple users in a short period of time. Monitoring such activities helps prevent sensitive data from being exposed or shared too broadly

rule.description: MSO365: User Added File Uploaded, and File Accessed by More Than 10 Users in 1 hour.
rule.info: Description: This correlation rule identifies when a new external user is added to a Microsoft Teams group, a file is uploaded, and then accessed by more than 10 different users within a one-hour window in the IFFCO tenant. This sequence of activities may indicate potential malicious actions, such as a compromised user distributing sensitive files through Microsoft Teams, or a coordinated insider threat using an external account for data exfiltration.

rule.description: MSO365: User Added, File Uploaded, and File Accessed by More Than 10 Users Within 1 Hour, and User Removed
rule.info: Description: This correlation rule detects a sequence where an external user is added to a Microsoft Teams group, a file is uploaded, the file is accessed by more than 10 users within 1 hour, and the external user is removed from the team. This behavior can indicate suspicious or malicious activities, such as an external actor being used to upload and spread a file, followed by quick removal to cover traces.
